title: Exploration
text:
Exploration is the act of searching for the purpose of <a href="discovery%20%28observation%29">discovery</a> of <a href="information">information</a> or resources, especially in the context of <a href="geography">geography</a> or <a href="space%20exploration">space</a>, rather than <a href="research%20and%20development">research and development</a> that is usually not centred on <a href="earth%20sciences">earth sciences</a> or <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>. Exploration occurs in all <a href="Sessility%20%28motility%29">non-sessile</a> animal species, including humans. In human <a href="history">history</a>, its most dramatic rise was during the <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a> when <a href="European%20peoples">European</a> explorers sailed and charted much of the rest of the world for a variety of reasons. Since then, <a href="major%20explorations%20after%20the%20Age%20of%20Discovery">major explorations after the Age of Discovery</a> have occurred for reasons mostly aimed at information discovery.
Concept.
Exploration (like <a href="Scientific%20racism">science more generally</a>), particularly its understanding and use has been critically discussed as historically being framed and used, at the latest since the <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a> up to the contemporary age of <a href="space%20exploration">space exploration</a>, for <a href="colonialism">colonialistic</a> ventures, discrimination and <a href="Exploitation%20colonialism">exploitation</a>, by reinvigorating concepts such as the "<a href="frontier">frontier</a>" (as in <a href="Frontier%20thesis">frontierism</a>) and <a href="manifest%20destiny">manifest destiny</a>.
Notable historical periods of human exploration.
Phoenician galley sailings.
The Phoenicians (1550 BCE–300 BCE) traded throughout the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> and <a href="Asia%20Minor">Asia Minor</a> though many of their routes are still unknown today. The presence of tin in some Phoenician artifacts suggests that they may have traveled to <a href="United%20Kingdom">Britain</a>. According to <a href="Virgil">Virgil</a>'s <a href="Aeneid">Aeneid</a> and other ancient sources, the legendary Queen <a href="Dido">Dido</a> was a Phoenician from <a href="Tyre%2C%20Lebanon">Tyre</a> who sailed to <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a> and founded the city of <a href="Carthage">Carthage</a>.
Carthaginean exploration of Western Africa.
<a href="Hanno%20the%20Navigator">Hanno the Navigator</a> (500 BC), a <a href="Carthage">Carthaginean</a> navigator who explored the Western Coast of <a href="Africa">Africa</a>.
Roman explorations.
The Romans organized expeditions to cross the <a href="Sahara">Sahara</a> desert with five different routes:
All these expeditions were supported by <a href="Legionary">legionaries</a> and had mainly a commercial purpose. Only the one done by emperor <a href="Nero">Nero</a> seemed to be a preparative for the conquest of <a href="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> or <a href="Nubia">Nubia</a>: in 62 AD two legionaries explored the sources of the Nile river.
One of the main reasons of the explorations was to get gold using the camel to transport it.
The explorations near the African western and eastern coasts were supported by Roman ships and deeply related to the naval commerce (mainly toward the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>).
The Romans also organized <a href="Germanic%E2%80%93Roman%20contacts">several explorations into Northern Europe</a>, and <a href="Sino-Roman%20relations">explored as far as China</a> in <a href="Asia">Asia</a>.
Chinese exploration of Central Asia.
During the 2nd century BC, the <a href="Han%20dynasty">Han dynasty</a> explored much of the Eastern Northern Hemisphere. Starting in 139 BC, the Han diplomat <a href="Zhang%20Qian">Zhang Qian</a> traveled west in an unsuccessful attempt to secure an alliance with the Da <a href="Yuezhi">Yuezhi</a> against the <a href="Xiongnu">Xiongnu</a> (the Yuezhi had been evicted from <a href="Gansu">Gansu</a> by the Xiongnu in 177 BC); however, Zhang's travels discovered entire countries which the Chinese were unaware of, including the <a href="Hellenistic%20civilization">remnants of the conquests</a> of <a href="Alexander%20the%20Great">Alexander the Great</a> (r. 336–323 BC). When Zhang returned to China in 125 BC, he reported on his visits to <a href="Dayuan">Dayuan</a> (<a href="Fergana">Fergana</a>), <a href="Kangju">Kangju</a> (<a href="Sogdia">Sogdia</a>), and <a href="Daxia">Daxia</a> (<a href="Bactria">Bactria</a>, formerly the <a href="Greco-Bactrian%20Kingdom">Greco-Bactrian Kingdom</a> which had just been subjugated by the Da Yuezhi). Zhang described Dayuan and Daxia as agricultural and urban countries like China, and although he did not venture there, described Shendu (the <a href="Indus%20River">Indus River</a> valley of Northwestern India) and Anxi (<a href="Parthian%20Empire">Parthian</a> territories) further west.
Viking Age.
From about 800 AD to 1040 AD, the <a href="Vikings">Vikings</a> explored Iceland and much of the Western Northern Hemisphere via rivers and oceans. For example, it is known that the <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> <a href="Viking">Viking</a> explorer, <a href="Erik%20the%20Red">Erik the Red</a> (950–1003), sailed to and settled in <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> after being expelled from <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>, while his son, the <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>ic explorer <a href="Leif%20Erikson">Leif Erikson</a> (980–1020), reached <a href="Newfoundland">Newfoundland</a> and the nearby North American coast, and is believed to be the first <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an to land in <a href="North%20America">North America</a>.
Polynesian Age.
<a href="Polynesians">Polynesians</a> were a maritime people, who populated and explored the central and <a href="Oceania">south Pacific</a> for around 5,000 years, up to about 1280 when they discovered <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. The key invention to their exploration was the <a href="outrigger%20canoe">outrigger canoe</a>, which provided a swift and stable platform for carrying goods and people. Based on limited evidence, it is thought that the voyage to New Zealand was deliberate. It is unknown if one or more boats went to New Zealand, or the type of boat, or the names of those who migrated. 2011 studies at <a href="Wairau%20Bar">Wairau Bar</a> in New Zealand show a high probability that one origin was Ruahine Island in the <a href="Society%20Islands">Society Islands</a>. Polynesians may have used the prevailing north easterly <a href="trade%20winds">trade winds</a> to reach New Zealand in about three weeks. The Cook Islands are in direct line along the migration path and may have been an intermediate stopping point. There are cultural and language similarities between <a href="Cook%20Islanders">Cook Islanders</a> and New Zealand <a href="M%C4%81ori%20people">Māori</a>. Early Māori had different legends of their origins, but the stories were misunderstood and reinterpreted in confused written accounts by early European historians in New Zealand trying to present a coherent pattern of Māori settlement in New Zealand.
Mathematical modelling based on DNA <a href="Identity%20by%20descent">genome studies</a>, using <a href="state%20of%20the%20art">state of the art</a> techniques, have shown that a large number of Polynesian migrants (100–200), including women, arrived in New Zealand around the same time, in about 1280. <a href="Otago%20University">Otago University</a> studies have tried to link distinctive DNA teeth patterns, which show special dietary influence, with places in or nearby the <a href="Society%20Islands">Society Islands</a>.
Chinese exploration of the Indian Ocean.
The Chinese explorer, <a href="Wang%20Dayuan">Wang Dayuan</a> (<a href="floruit">fl.</a> 1311–1350) made two major trips by ship to the Indian Ocean. During 1328–1333, he sailed along the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a> and visited many places in <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and reached as far as <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>, landing in <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and <a href="India">India</a>, and he even went to <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. Then in 1334–1339, he visited <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a> and <a href="East%20Africa">East Africa</a>. Later, the Chinese admiral <a href="Zheng%20He">Zheng He</a> (1371–1433) made <a href="Ming%20treasure%20voyages">seven voyages</a> to <a href="Arabia">Arabia</a>, <a href="East%20Africa">East Africa</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>.
European Age of Discovery.
The <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>, also known as the Age of Exploration, is one of the most important periods of geographical exploration in human history. It started in the early 15th century and lasted until the 17th century. In that period, Europeans discovered and/or explored vast areas of the Americas, Africa, Asia and Oceania. <a href="Portuguese%20empire">Portugal</a> and <a href="Spanish%20empire">Spain</a> dominated the first stages of exploration, while other European nations followed, such as <a href="British%20empire">England</a>, <a href="Dutch%20empire">Netherlands</a>, and <a href="French%20colonial%20empire">France</a>.
Important explorations during this period went to a number of continents and regions around the globe. In Africa, important explorers of this period include <a href="Diogo%20C%C3%A3o">Diogo Cão</a> (1452-1486) who discovered and ascended the <a href="Congo%20River">Congo River</a> and reached the coasts of present-day <a href="Angola">Angola</a> and <a href="Namibia">Namibia</a>; and <a href="Bartolomeu%20Dias">Bartolomeu Dias</a> (1450–1500), the first European to reach the <a href="Cape%20of%20Good%20Hope">Cape of Good Hope</a> and other parts of the <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n coast.
Explorers of routes from Europe towards Asia, the Indian Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean, include <a href="Vasco%20da%20Gama">Vasco da Gama</a> (1460–1524), a navigator who made the first trip from Europe to India and back by the Cape of Good Hope, discovering the ocean route to the <a href="East">East</a>; <a href="Pedro%20%C3%81lvares%20Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a> (c. 1467/1468 – c. 1520) who, following the path of Vasco da Gama, claimed <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> and led the first expedition that linked Europe, Africa, America, and Asia; <a href="Diogo%20Dias">Diogo Dias</a>, who discovered the eastern coast of <a href="Madagascar">Madagascar</a> and rounded the corner of Africa; explorers such as <a href="Diogo%20Fernandes%20Pereira">Diogo Fernandes Pereira</a> and <a href="Pedro%20Mascarenhas">Pedro Mascarenhas</a> (1470–1555), among others, who discovered and mapped the <a href="Mascarene%20Islands">Mascarene Islands</a> and other archipelagos.
<a href="Ant%C3%B3nio%20de%20Abreu">António de Abreu</a> (1480-1514) and <a href="Francisco%20Serr%C3%A3o">Francisco Serrão</a> (14?–1521) led the first direct European fleet into the Pacific Ocean (on its western edges) and through the <a href="Sunda%20Islands">Sunda Islands</a>, reaching the <a href="Moluccas">Moluccas</a>. <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20de%20Urdaneta">Andrés de Urdaneta</a> (1498–1568) discovered the maritime route from Asia to the Americas.
In the Pacific Ocean, <a href="Jorge%20de%20Menezes">Jorge de Menezes</a> (1498–1537) reached <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a> while <a href="Loa%C3%ADsa%20expedition">García Jofre de Loaísa</a> (1490–1526) reached the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a>.
Explorations of the Americas began with the initial discovery of America by <a href="Christopher%20Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> (1451–1506), who led a <a href="Crown%20of%20Castile">Castilian</a> (<a href="Spanish%20Empire">Spanish</a>) expedition across the Atlantic, <a href="Voyages%20of%20Christopher%20Columbus">discovering America</a>. After the discovery of America by Columbus, a number of important expeditions were sent out to explore the Western Hemisphere. This included <a href="Juan%20Ponce%20de%20Le%C3%B3n">Juan Ponce de León</a> (1474–1521), who discovered and mapped the coast of <a href="Florida">Florida</a>; <a href="Vasco%20N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez%20de%20Balboa">Vasco Núñez de Balboa</a> (c. 1475–1519), who was the first European to view the Pacific Ocean from American shores (after crossing the <a href="Isthmus%20of%20Panama">Isthmus of Panama</a>) confirming that America was a separate continent from Asia; <a href="Aleixo%20Garcia">Aleixo Garcia</a> (14?–1527), who explored the territories of present-day southern Brazil, <a href="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> and <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, crossing the <a href="Gran%20Chaco">Chaco</a> and reaching the <a href="Andes">Andes</a> (near <a href="Sucre">Sucre</a>).
<a href="%C3%81lvar%20N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez%20Cabeza%20de%20Vaca">Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca</a> (1490–1558) discovered the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a> and was the first European to sail the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> and cross <a href="Texas">Texas</a>. <a href="Jacques%20Cartier">Jacques Cartier</a> (1491–1557) drew the first maps of part of central and maritime Canada; <a href="Francisco%20V%C3%A1zquez%20de%20Coronado">Francisco Vázquez de Coronado</a> (1510–1554) discovered the <a href="Grand%20Canyon">Grand Canyon</a> and the <a href="Colorado%20River">Colorado River</a>; <a href="Francisco%20de%20Orellana">Francisco de Orellana</a> (1511–1546) was the first European to navigate the length of the <a href="Amazon%20River">Amazon River</a>.
<a href="Ferdinand%20Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> (1480–1521), was the first navigator to cross the Pacific Ocean, discovering the <a href="Strait%20of%20Magellan">Strait of Magellan</a>, the <a href="Tuamotus">Tuamotus</a> and <a href="Mariana%20Islands">Mariana Islands</a>, and achieving a nearly complete <a href="circumnavigation">circumnavigation</a> of the Earth, in multiple voyages, for the first time. <a href="Juan%20Sebasti%C3%A1n%20Elcano">Juan Sebastián Elcano</a> (1476–1526), completed the first <a href="Timeline%20of%20Magellan%27s%20circumnavigation">global circumnavigation</a>.
In the second half of the 16th century and the 17th century exploration of Asia and the Pacific Ocean continued with explorers such as <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20de%20Urdaneta">Andrés de Urdaneta</a> (1498–1568), who discovered the maritime route from Asia to the Americas; <a href="Pedro%20Fernandes%20de%20Queir%C3%B3s">Pedro Fernandes de Queirós</a> (1565–1614), who discovered the <a href="Pitcairn%20Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a> and the <a href="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a> archipelago; <a href="%C3%81lvaro%20de%20Menda%C3%B1a%20de%20Neira">Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira</a> (1542–1595), who discovered the <a href="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a> archipelago, the <a href="Marquesas%20Islands">Marquesas</a>, the <a href="Solomon%20Islands">Solomon Islands</a> and <a href="Wake%20Island">Wake Island</a>.
Explorers of Australia included <a href="Willem%20Janszoon">Willem Janszoon</a> (1570–1630), who made the first recorded European landing in Australia; <a href="Y%C3%B1igo%20Ortiz%20de%20Retez">Yñigo Ortiz de Retez</a>, who discovered and reached eastern and northern <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>; <a href="Luis%20V%C3%A1ez%20de%20Torres">Luis Váez de Torres</a> (1565–1613), who discovered the <a href="Torres%20Strait">Torres Strait</a> between <a href="Australia">Australia</a> and <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>; <a href="Abel%20Tasman">Abel Tasman</a> (1603–1659), who explored North Australia, discovered <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> and <a href="Tongatapu">Tongatapu</a>.
In North America, major explorers included <a href="Henry%20Hudson">Henry Hudson</a> (156?–1611), who explored the <a href="Hudson%20Bay">Hudson Bay</a> in Canada; <a href="Samuel%20de%20Champlain">Samuel de Champlain</a> (1574–1635), who explored <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20River">St. Lawrence River</a> and the <a href="Great%20Lakes">Great Lakes</a> (in Canada and northern United States); and <a href="Ren%C3%A9-Robert%20Cavelier%2C%20Sieur%20de%20La%20Salle">René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle</a> (1643–1687), who explored the Great Lakes region of the United States and Canada, and the entire length of the Mississippi River.
The Modern Age.
Long after the golden age of discovery, other explorers "completed" the world map, such as various <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russians</a> explorers, reaching the <a href="Siberia">Siberia</a>n Pacific coast and the <a href="Bering%20Strait">Bering Strait</a>, at the extreme edge of Asia and <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a> (North America); <a href="Vitus%20Bering">Vitus Bering</a> (1681–1741) who in the service of the Russian Navy, explored the Bering Strait, the <a href="Bering%20Sea">Bering Sea</a>, the North American coast of Alaska, and some other northern areas of the Pacific Ocean; and <a href="James%20Cook">James Cook</a>, who explored the east coast of Australia, the <a href="Hawaiian%20Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a>, and circumnavigated <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
There were still significant explorations which occurred well into the modern age. This includes the <a href="Lewis%20and%20Clark%20Expedition">Lewis and Clark Expedition</a> (1804-1806), an overland expedition dispatched by President <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> to explore the newly acquired Louisiana Purchase and to find an interior aquatic route to the Pacific Ocean, along with other objectives to examine the flora and fauna of the continent. In 1818, the British researcher <a href="John%20Ross%20%28Arctic%20explorer%29">Sir John Ross</a> was the first to find that the deep sea is inhabited by life when catching <a href="jellyfish">jellyfish</a> and <a href="worm">worm</a>s in about depth with a special device. The <a href="United%20States%20Exploring%20Expedition">United States Exploring Expedition</a> (1838-1842) was an expedition sent by President <a href="Andrew%20Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a>, in order to survey the Pacific Ocean and surrounding lands.
The extreme conditions in the deep sea require elaborate methods and technologies to endure them. In the 20th century, deep-sea exploration advanced considerably through a series of technological inventions, ranging from the <a href="sonar">sonar</a> system, which can detect the presence of objects underwater through the use of sound, to manned <a href="Deep-submergence%20vehicle">deep-diving submersibles</a>. In 1960, <a href="Jacques%20Piccard">Jacques Piccard</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> Lieutenant <a href="Don%20Walsh">Donald Walsh</a> descended in the <a href="bathyscaphe">bathyscaphe</a> <a href="Bathyscaphe%20Trieste">"Trieste"</a> into the deepest part of the world's oceans, the <a href="Mariana%20Trench">Mariana Trench</a>. In 2018, , piloted by <a href="Victor%20Vescovo">Victor Vescovo</a>, completed the first mission to the deepest point of the Atlantic Ocean, diving below the ocean surface to the base of the <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Trench">Puerto Rico Trench</a>. With the advent of satellite imagery and aviation, exploration of the surface of <a href="Earth">Earth</a> has largely ceased, however the culture of many disconnected tribes still remain undocumented and left to be explored. Urban exploration is the exploration of manmade structures, usually abandoned ruins or hidden components of the manmade environment.
Space exploration.
<a href="Space%20exploration">Space exploration</a> started in the 20th century with the invention of exo-atmospheric <a href="rocket">rocket</a>s. This has given humans the opportunity to travel to the <a href="Moon">Moon</a>, and to send robotic explorers to other <a href="planet">planet</a>s and far beyond.
Both of the <a href="Voyager%20program">Voyager probes</a> have left the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a>, bearing imprinted gold discs with multiple data types.
Behavioral trait.
A 2015 study, performed on mobile phone data and on GPS tracks of private vehicles in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, demonstrated that individuals naturally split into two well-defined categories according to their mobility habits, dubbed "returners" and "explorers". 
"Explorers" showed a star-like mobility pattern: they have a central core of locations (composed by home and work places) around which distant core of locations gravitates.
